facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 359 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 359 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated April 18, 1960, of the Third Industrial Tribunal West Bengal, in case No. VIII 153 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated April 18, 1960, of the Third Industrial, Tribunal west Bengal, in case No. VIII 153 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 5. The Judgment of the companyrt was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This appeal by special leave arises out of a question of bonus

facts.text: Appellant is a company carrying on business in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the companyrt was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This appeal by special leave arises out of a question of bonus referred by the Government of West Bengal to the Third Industrial Tribunal. The appellant is a companypany carrying on business in Calcutta

facts.text: Dispute relates to closing bonus for the year 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companypany carrying on business in Calcutta and the dispute relates to closing bonus for the year 1958.

facts.text: Appellant paid closing bonus at the rate of one month's pay from 1948 to 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant had been paying, a, bonus which was called closing bonus. to its workmen at the rate of one months pay from 1948 to 1957.

facts.text: In 1958, quantum of closing bonus reduced to half a month's pay due to fall in profits.

anchor.surface_text: In 1958, however, as the profits of the appellant fell companysider. ably, the quantum of closing, bonus was reduced to half a months pay.

facts.text: Dispute raised by respondents workmen represented by two unions claiming one month's bonus as usual.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence a dispute was raised by the respondents workmen represented by two unions and their claim was that they should have been paid one months bonus as usual.

facts.text: Reference made to the Third Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently reference was made to the tribunal and the question for decision was whether the management was justified in reducing the quantum of closing bonus to half a months pay in 1958.

facts.text: Workmen claimed closing bonus paid at uniform rate from 1948 to 1957 became implied condition of service.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the workmen was that the appellant had been paying two kinds of bonuses to its workmen each year, namely,  1  Puja bonus which ,was paid usually before the Puja festival, and  ii  closing bonus which was paid after the close of the financial year ending on March 31st each year. The workmen claimed that closing bonus had been paid at a uniform rate from 1948 to 1957 and this payment had therefore become an implied companydition of service

facts.text: Alternative claim: payment acquired character of customary bonus not dependent on profits.

anchor.surface_text: between the workmen and the appellant in the alternative the claim was that the payment had acquired the character of customary bonus and was number dependent upon profits earned by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contended closing bonus is profit bonus dependent on profits.

anchor.surface_text: On the other band the companytention of the appellant was that the payment of closing bonus at a uniform rate of one months pay for ten years previous to 1958 had number in fact turned the payment into an implied companydition of service as this bonus was of the nature of profit bonus and its payment depended upon the profits made by the appellant.

facts.text: Closing bonus paid after accounts made up and profit ascertained.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged further that the very fact that this bonus was paid after the accounts for the year were made up and the profit ascertained showed that it was a bonus depending upon profits

facts.text: Puja bonus increased as profits increased.

anchor.surface_text: the circumstance that it was paid at a uniform rate for sometime was only fortuitous, particularly as the appellant had increased the Puja bonus as its profits increased in order to help the workmen at festival time.

facts.text: Tribunal held not proved as implied condition of service, relied on Isprahani case.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal came to the companyclusion that it had number been proved that the payment of closing bonus had become an implied companydition of service and in that companynection relied on the decision of this Court in Messrs. Isprahani Limited Calcutta v. Ispahani Employees Union.

facts.text: Tribunal held not customary bonus as not paid in year of loss.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it held that the bonus companyld number be held to be a customary bonus as there was numberhing to show that it had been paid even in a year of loss.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded additional half month's basic salary as profit bonus based on Full-Bench formula.

anchor.surface_text: It held that there sufficient available surplus to warrant payment of one months pay as profits bonus and therefore ordered that half a, months basic salary be further paid as profit bonus to the workmen for the year in dispute.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed 2.5% interest on paid-up capital because dividend was 2.5%.

anchor.surface_text: So far as profit bonus is companycerned, the main companytention on behalf of the appellant is that the tribunal went wrong in allowing 2 1/2 per centum interest on paid-up capital and that itshoud have allowed, 6 per interest, which is the usual amount allowed under the Full-Bench formula.

facts.text: Appellant paid dividend at 2.5% in 1958 due to fall in profits.

anchor.surface_text: The reason why the tribunal allowed 2 1/2 Per centum interest was that the appellant, had paid dividend at 2 1/2 per centum in that year as its  1  1960 1 S.C.R. 24.  2  1959 S.C.R, 925. profits bad show a companysiderable fall.

facts.text: Supreme Court held tribunal wrong in allowing only 2.5% interest; should be 6%.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the tribunal was wrong in allowing only 2 1/2 per centum interest on paid-up capital on the ground that the actual dividend declared by the appellant was only 2 1/2 per centum for that year.

facts.text: With 6% interest, no available surplus for further bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed by learned companynsel for the respondents that if six per centum interest is allowed on paid-up capital in this case as is usually done there will be numberjustification for allowing more as profit bonus than what the appellant has already given.

facts.text: Closing bonus not connected with any festival.

anchor.surface_text: So far as customary bonus is companycerned, it is enough to say that customary bonus of the nature dealt with in Graham Trading Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen 1  is always companynected with some festival. In the present case it is number in dispute that the closing bonus is number companynected with any festival

facts.text: Company formerly belonged to another owner, merged with appellant in 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Besides it appears that this companypany formerly belonged to another owner and merged with the appellant in 1946.

facts.text: Previous company did not pay closing bonus from 1940 to 1945.

anchor.surface_text: When the former companypany was the owner it does number appear that it paid any closing bonus as such from 1940 to 1945.

facts.text: No closing bonus paid in 1946 and 1947 after takeover.

anchor.surface_text: Even after the appellant took over numberpayment was made in 1946 and 1947.

facts.text: Closing bonus of one month's basic wages paid from 1948 after trading results for year ending March 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It was only from 1948 after the trading results for the year ending on March 31, 1948 were known that one months basic wages began to be paid as closing bonus

facts.text: Puja bonus originally one month's basic wages, increased to two months from 1955.

anchor.surface_text: in addition to puja bonus which was originally paid at the rat , of one months basic wages but which was gradually in- creased to two months basic wages from 1955.

facts.text: For 1958, paid two months Puja bonus, closing bonus half month due to profits fall from Rs. 27 lacs in 1957 to over Rs. 15 lacs in 1958.

anchor.surface_text: For the year in dispute the appellant has paid two months puja bonus but it reduced the closing bonus from one month to half a months basic wages because of the fall in profits which fell from Rs. 27 lacs in 19,57 to a little over Rs. 15 lacs in- 1958.

facts.text: In 1959, when profits went up, paid one month's pay as closing bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that in 1959 when profits went up again the appellant has paid one months pay as closing bonus.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, tribunal order set aside, claim rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the tribunal and reject the claim of the workmen for any closing bonus over and above that paid by the appellant for the year 1958.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the tribunal was wrong in allowing only 2 1/2 per centum interest on paid-up capital on the ground that the actual dividend declared by the appellant was only 2 1/2 per centum for that year. holdings.text: The tribunal was wrong in allowing only 2 1/2 per centum interest on paid-up capital on the ground that the actual dividend declared by the appellant was only 2 1/2 per centum for that year. The return on paid-up capital provided in the Full-Bench formula is not linked with actual dividends

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the tribunal was wrong in allowing only 2 1/2 per centum interest on paid-up capital on the ground that the actual dividend declared by the appellant was only 2 1/2 per centum for that year. The return on paid-up capital provided in the Full-Bench formula is not linked with actual dividends

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full-Bench formula prescribes usual 6% on paid-up capital irrespective of dividends declared unless exceptional case shown; no such exception here

holdings.text: The tribunal should have allowed six per centum interest on paid-up capital in this case and that would increase the amount due under this head from Rs. 5 lacs to Rs. 12 lacs

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the tribunal should have allowed six per centum interest on paid-up capital in this case and that would increase the amount due under this head from Rs. 5 lacs to Rs. 12 lacs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of standard Full-Bench formula rate

holdings.reasoning_summary: With correct 6% interest calculation, no available surplus remains for additional profit bonus

holdings.text: customary bonus of the nature dealt with in Graham Trading Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen is always connected with some festival. In the present case it is not in dispute that the closing bonus is not connected with any festival and therefore cannot be treated as customary bonus

holdings.reasoning_summary: Customary bonus requires festival connection per Graham Trading and B.N. Elias precedents; closing bonus lacks this

holdings.text: it cannot be held that one months pay as closing bonus is payable as an implied condition of service irrespective of the profit made by the appellant. It seems to have been of the nature of profit bonus, even though it may have been paid at a uniform rate for ten years
holdings.reasoning_summary: Paid post-profit ascertainment, no loss-year payment, historical non-uniformity pre-1948, variable with profits; follows Isprahani

holdings.text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the tribunal and reject the claim of the workmen for any closing bonus over and above that paid by the appellant for the year 1958

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the tribunal and reject the claim of the workmen for any closing bonus over and above that paid by the appellant for the year 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All claims rejected: not implied/customary; no surplus for extra profit bonus under correct formula

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the tribunal was wrong in allowing only 2 1/2 per centum interest on paid-up capital on the ground that the actual dividend declared by the appellant was only 2 1/2 per centum for that year. The return on paid-up capital provided in the Full-Bench formula is not linked with actual dividends
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the tribunal and reject the claim of the workmen for any closing bonus over and above that paid by the appellant for the year 1958.

anchor.surface_text: So far as customary bonus is concerned, it is enough to say that customary bonus of the nature dealt with in Graham Trading Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen 1  is always connected with some festival. In the present case it is not in dispute that the closing bonus is not connected with any festival
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the tribunal and reject the claim of the workmen for any closing bonus over and above that paid by the appellant for the year 1958.
